Abandoned

Nobody willing to own this feature at this time.
Where is this defined? I don't see it upstream code.
this commit is dependent to this commit https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/52075/31 and its defined in it.
Use crow::utility::urlFromPieces for forming the URL.

I couldn't find the computerSystemIndex related changes, It might be dependent on other patches, If so, please do add dependency in topic. 

In OpenBMC "system" is default name used, But i see this code assign Index 0 to "Host" so not clear where exactly these are defined. Is there any design document associated with it which i missed?
Please follow the 50/72 commit message rule.
Could you also mention service validator results?

I'm wondering why the systemName is always expected to start with 'system'.  This does not conform to the DMTF Redfish ComputerSystem schema or mockups which show other values such as the serial number can be used to indicate the system names in a multi-host mockup (https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1207).  We should allow the system names to be driven by the platform configuration and not hard-coded.

> This does not conform to the DMTF Redfish ComputerSystem schema

Can you expand on this?  I believe we are in-line with what the specification allows.

The mockups are not normative, they are examples, and do not set the limits of what a conforming redfish instance is allowed to do.

> We should allow the system names to be driven by the platform configuration and not hard-coded.

No disagreement this would be an improvement, but implementing this is non-trivial.  Is this something you're interested in pushing patches to accomplish?  I would expect it could be done similarly to how Name is used in EM.

Ed, sorry yes, you are correct.  The use of 'system' is in alignment with the Redfish schema.  What I wanted to convey was captured much better in your last statement.  I was expecting some flexibility in the system names and was unaware of the extensive hard coding of URIs in the bmcweb code.  Since this is expected, I'll remove my -1 on this patchset.

Feel free to send patches that make the code meet your expectations closer.  Happy to discuss how to make this stuff better handled by code, and there is some precidence for it, but hardcoding IDs like this is a HUUUUUUGE complexity simplification, so we'll need to figure out how to manage what you want in code.
Marking this comment as done as it was about the hard-coding of "system" to determine the difference between single and multi-host systems.  Changes to this can be done at a later time.

Could you combine these two branches?

systemName != "system" && !(collection_util::isValidSystem(computerSystemIndex))
Should this be systemName to be consistent with supporting multi-host systems?
I don't think so?  That would break the redfish tree.
OK, my confusion as this function has systemIdx passed in.  In other places in this file, the systemName variable is used to build the URI such as lines 1059-1060 and 1110-1111.

Same here...

Looking at the DMTF Redfish multi-host mockups at https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1207, under the Systems, the name of the system can be a multitude of things including the serial number of each sled.  We should not be hardcoding this to 'system#.

Agreed. The system prefix is right now used because at the moment "system" is being used as the system name for all other platforms. if we need to change the system name to serial number we need to ensure all the platforms serial number can be read with a common dbus interface,  Ed Tanous could you suggest on making serial number as system name is possible right now for any platform(single host and multihost) or do we expect any dependency from other apps w.r.t the system name change so that we keep "system" as system name for now and migrate to serial number as system name in future?

My opinion is:
1. Constraining URIs to "system" and "system<N>" is perfectly fine for now, and allowed in the Redfish specification.
2. URIs are opaque by definition in the spec, so whether we use a hash, an id, an index, or a human-readable string, is at the discretion of bmcweb.
3. There are LOTS of other places where we hardcode URI ids in non system-specific ways.
4. The mockups are an _example_.  They can not and do not convey all requirements in the spec, so if someone is trying to make the argument that we don't follow the specification, they need to use wording in the specification to do it, not that we don't follow the mockups.  There's almost no case where we follow the mockups 100%.
5. At such time as someone is willing to put forward the significant effort to make the names configurable per system, we can hardcode the existing systems to what they are today (ie system and system<n>), so I don't see this patch being a significant impediment to making URIs configurable in the future.

The comment was not meant to say the mockups should be followed 100%.  The concern was around hard-coding the value of system<N>.  Since this is done elsewhere in the code, my comment is out of place.

Please forgive me for the comments as I'm still learning the codebase and community expectations.
Assuming the systemName will always by 'system' is not in alignment with the DMTF Redfish schemas which allow for other names here.
Please quote the specification section you're referring to.  To my undestanding "system" is allowed in the naming convention for Ids.
We should not be forcing the systemname to always be 'system' or start with 'system'.
is this patch still in progress?
Second request.  Anyone still working on this?

HCL is no longer doing development related to Meta's OpenBMC system support.  We will revive this work, but probably not for a few months.  It is acceptable to close if you want for the time being, but ideally whoever picks it up will start from this patch set.
Cool.  I'm going to abandon this so it falls off the list.  Feel free to reopen when someone pops up to keep working on this.
